sn3.22:4.2: King Pasenadi of Kosala sat to one side, and the Buddha said to him:
sn3.22:4.3: “So, Great King, where are you coming from in the middle of the day?”
sn3.22:5.1: “Sir, my grandmother has died. She was old, elderly and senior. She had lived long and reached the final stage of life; she was a hundred and twenty years old.
sn3.22:5.2: But I loved my grandmother; she was dear to me.
sn3.22:5.3: If by giving away the elephant treasure I could get my grandmother back, I’d do it.
sn3.22:5.5: If by giving away the horse treasure I could get my grandmother back, I’d do it.
sn3.22:5.7: If by giving away a prize village I could get my grandmother back, I’d do it.
sn3.22:5.9: If by giving away the whole country I could get my grandmother back, I’d do it.”
sn3.22:5.11: “Great King, all sentient beings are liable to die. Death is their end; they’re not exempt from death.”
sn3.22:5.13: how well said this was by the Buddha:
sn3.22:5.14: ‘All sentient beings are liable to die. Death is their end; they’re not exempt from death.’”
sn3.22:6.1: “That’s so true, Great King! That’s so true!
sn3.22:6.2: All sentient beings are liable to die. Death is their end; they’re not exempt from death.
sn3.22:6.3: It’s like the vessels made by potters. Whatever kind they are, whether baked or unbaked, all of them are liable to break apart. Breaking is their end; they’re not exempt from breakage.
sn3.22:6.4: In the same way, all sentient beings are liable to die. Death is their end; they’re not exempt from death.”
sn3.22:6.5: This is what the Buddha said. …
sn3.22:7.3: They pass on according to their deeds,
sn3.22:7.4: reaping the fruits of good and bad.
sn3.22:7.5: Those who do bad go to hell,
sn3.22:7.6: and if you do good you go to heaven.
sn3.22:8.1: That’s why you should do good,
sn3.22:8.3: The good deeds of sentient beings
sn3.22:8.4: support them in the next world.”
